questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presents with dyspnea on exertion and occasional palpitations. A chest X-ray is performed, revealing the cardiac silhouette. Study the image provided and answer the following question. Which of the following statements regarding the heart's position, size, and borders on the chest radiograph is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: The right heart border is formed primarily by the right ventricle.

options.label: B
options.text: The left atrium primarily forms the left heart border.

options.label: C
options.text: The cardiothoracic ratio (CTR) is considered normal if it is less than 0.5 on a PA chest X-ray.

options.label: D
options.text: The right atrium and the left ventricle mainly form the inferior border of the heart.

questions.correct_answer: C. The cardiothoracic ratio (CTR) is considered normal if it is less than 0.5 on a PA chest X-ray.

questions.text: A 5-month-old male infant presents with cyanosis, difficulty breathing, and failure to thrive. On physical examination, a loud second heart sound (S2) is heard, and there are signs of pulmonary congestion. The patient’s chest X-ray is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.correct_answer: D. Total anomalous pulmonary venous connection (TAPVC)

questions.text: A 16-year-old female presents to the emergency department with complaints of shortness of breath and palpitations. A chest X-ray is performed, and the radiologist notes a distinctive cardiac silhouette, as shown in the image. Which of the following best describes the cardiac abnormality suggested by this radiographic appearance?

options.label: C
options.text: Egg-on-string appearance; Transposition of the Great Arteries

options.label: D
options.text: Snowman sign; Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Return

questions.text: A 70-year-old male patient presents to the emergency department with acute respiratory distress following a severe allergic reaction. He has a history of asthma and reports recent exposure to a known allergen. Chest X-ray of the patient is given below. Which of the following findings on the chest X-ray is NOT characteristic of the patient’s condition?
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Interstitial Edema Signs: Kerley B Lines: Short horizontal lines at lung periphery due to fluid in the interlobular septa. (Option D ruled out) Kerley A Lines: Longer lines directed towards the hilum (more difficult to detect). Peribronchial Cuffing: Thickening and blurring of airway walls due to fluid accumulation. Perihilar Haze: Blurring of central lung vessels due to fluid in perivascular spaces.
  • ↳ Interstitial Edema Signs:
  • ↳ Kerley B Lines: Short horizontal lines at lung periphery due to fluid in the interlobular septa. (Option D ruled out) Kerley A Lines: Longer lines directed towards the hilum (more difficult to detect). Peribronchial Cuffing: Thickening and blurring of airway walls due to fluid accumulation. Perihilar Haze: Blurring of central lung vessels due to fluid in perivascular spaces.
  • ↳ Kerley B Lines: Short horizontal lines at lung periphery due to fluid in the interlobular septa. (Option D ruled out)
  • ↳ Kerley B Lines:
  • ↳ (Option D ruled out)
  • ↳ Kerley A Lines: Longer lines directed towards the hilum (more difficult to detect).
  • ↳ Kerley A Lines:
  • ↳ Peribronchial Cuffing: Thickening and blurring of airway walls due to fluid accumulation.
  • ↳ Peribronchial Cuffing:
  • ↳ Perihilar Haze: Blurring of central lung vessels due to fluid in perivascular spaces.
  • ↳ Perihilar Haze:
  • ↳ Alveolar Edema Signs: Bilateral Opacification: Fluid in alveoli causing diffuse clouding of lung fields. Bat’s Wing Distribution: Central lung opacities with sparing of the peripheries. (Option A ruled out) Air Bronchogram: Visible air-filled bronchi surrounded by fluid-filled alveoli. (Option B ruled out) Rapid Changes in Opacity: Quick development of opacities suggests edema rather than infection.
  • ↳ Alveolar Edema Signs:
  • ↳ Bilateral Opacification: Fluid in alveoli causing diffuse clouding of lung fields. Bat’s Wing Distribution: Central lung opacities with sparing of the peripheries. (Option A ruled out) Air Bronchogram: Visible air-filled bronchi surrounded by fluid-filled alveoli. (Option B ruled out) Rapid Changes in Opacity: Quick development of opacities suggests edema rather than infection.
  • ↳ Bilateral Opacification: Fluid in alveoli causing diffuse clouding of lung fields.
  • ↳ Bilateral Opacification:
  • ↳ Bat’s Wing Distribution: Central lung opacities with sparing of the peripheries. (Option A ruled out)
  • ↳ Bat’s Wing Distribution:
  • ↳ (Option A ruled out)
  • ↳ Air Bronchogram: Visible air-filled bronchi surrounded by fluid-filled alveoli. (Option B ruled out)
  • ↳ Air Bronchogram:
  • ↳ (Option B ruled out)
  • ↳ Rapid Changes in Opacity: Quick development of opacities suggests edema rather than infection.
  • ↳ Rapid Changes in Opacity:
  • ↳ Other Findings: Pleural Effusions: Fluid can accumulate between the lung and pleura, seen at costophrenic angles. Upper Lobe Sparing: Edema often spares upper lobes, with a preference for lower lung zones. Peripheral Edema: In NCPE (like ARDS), peripheral lung regions may show more edema than central areas.
  • ↳ Other Findings:
  • ↳ Pleural Effusions: Fluid can accumulate between the lung and pleura, seen at costophrenic angles. Upper Lobe Sparing: Edema often spares upper lobes, with a preference for lower lung zones. Peripheral Edema: In NCPE (like ARDS), peripheral lung regions may show more edema than central areas.
  • ↳ Pleural Effusions: Fluid can accumulate between the lung and pleura, seen at costophrenic angles.
  • ↳ Pleural Effusions:
  • ↳ Upper Lobe Sparing: Edema often spares upper lobes, with a preference for lower lung zones.
  • ↳ Upper Lobe Sparing:
  • ↳ Peripheral Edema: In NCPE (like ARDS), peripheral lung regions may show more edema than central areas.
